posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked:
Hi,

I’d like to use signal desktop at work. It does not work out-of-the box: The QR-Code is not generated.
I can think of two reasons:

  1. We need to use a proxy to access the internet. Port 443 is open, but I did not find any option to configure a proxy in the Signal Desktop software itself. Does Signal Desktop make use of the proxy settings used in Windows 10, or is there any configuration option I’m not aware of?
  2. We are behind a firewall. Are this settings the ones, needed for signal destop: https://support.signal.org/hc/de/articles/360007320291-Einstellungen-für-Firewall-und-Internet?
    Thank you in advance for helping!

Yours, Johannes
I think you should contact your IT departement and ask them if access to Signal is blocked first.
Are you able to provide a debug log? (The Link, no screenshots or files)

posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked:
Signal Desktop is blocked - but not intentionally. Basically the IT blocks “everything” and opens if needed.

That’s why I do need to know, which URLs, Ports, Protocols (TCP/UDP) are exactly needed for Signal Desktop to work. 443/TCP is open, but Signal Desktop does not work (the QR-Code is not created). Also, if WebSockets are used, I need to know that - those do not work out-of-the-box and have to be opened, too. Same goes for certificate-pinning. We have SSL-Interception, so certs do not go through under standard-conditions.

That’s what the problem looks like:

Signal_Desktop_ERR971×633 47.6 KB

And here’s the debug log:

posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked:
TomatoPlant:

ink, no scre

I have not been able to upload, so I had to provide the text instead of the link.

I’m not an expert with the log files, but I found some information.

Port 443/TCP must be open for https.
WebSockets must be available via port 443.

The following URLs need to be whitelisted in the firewall:

  • *.signal.org
  • cdn.signal.org
  • storage.signal.org (for attachments)
  • updates.signal.org (for updates)

posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked:
Unfortunately, that did not do the trick…

Port 443/TCP must be open for https. => Yes, if URL is opened, which is the case for the URLs mentioned below.

WebSockets must be available via port 443. => Yes, if opened. URL based. Is opened for the URLs mentioned below.

The following URLs need to be whitelisted in the firewall:

  • *.signal.org => Wildcards are not allowed. I do have to specify every subdomain.
  • cdn.signal.org => TCP/443 open
  • storage.signal.org (for attachments) => TCP/443 open
  • updates.signal.org (for updates) => TCP/443 open

My questions:
a) Where do I get the list of which specific URLs/Ports/Protocols are needed?
b) Does Signal Desktop use the proxy which is specified in the windows-settings or do I have to specity the proxy on application level. If so: Where?

Thank you very much for helping!

A) I can’t find an official list.
B) This should be done via the system proxy, but why is IT blocking everything?

posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked:
A) That’s a pitty. Me neither. Without that info, Signal Desktop won’t work here :-( An ‘Inofficial List’ maybe would do, but I haven’t been able to get that information.

B) It is what it is. Let’s not go further down that road and focus instead on “what does the IT have to ‘unblock’ in order to make Signal Desktop work” :-)

P.S: Getting that list by “reverse engineering” is hard, too. I don’t have access to the proxy logs.

Megan:
  • *.signal.org
  • cdn.signal.org
  • storage.signal.org (for attachments)
  • updates.signal.org (for updates)

At least the above, but the main question is: Why do they block everything?

posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked: The problem may be *.signal.org. As I stated, I have to specify all needed subdomains. Wildcards will not work.

You should check with Wireshark which exact subdomains are being used. I can give you the following:

  • textsecure-service.whispersystems.org (most important API server)
  • api.directory.signal.org (contact management)
  • cdn.signal.org (content delivery, such as profile pictures)
  • storage.signal.org (storage of attachments)
  • updates.signal.org (updates)

If you want to make calls too:

  • relay.signal.org (call server, can use UDP)
  • voice.signal.org (calling via Signal)

Whitelist the above in the firewall and you should be able to use Signal. Check with WireShark what other domains are being used and whitelist them.

You can’t use a VPN eventually right?

posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked: Thank you very much for helping, I appreciate that a lot. Although, it seems to me, that this gets complicated. With 443/TCP open to the given list, SignaI Desktop still does not generate a QR code. I can’t use Wireshark (disallowed Software), the IT has tried that and given up… VPN is not an option, either. Without a list of URLs/Ports/Protocolls I doubt, that we can succeed.

I just wonder why IT is blocking everything, but everything linked above is added to the firewall?

Could you try to whitelist http://textsecure-service.whispersystems.org) which is being used to generate the QR code.

Also I’m happy to help you.

posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked:
Megan:

http://textsecure-service.whispersystems.org

Okay, maybe we are on the right track… textsecure-service.whispersystems.org ‘should’ be whitelisted already, but I get a ‘not reached’ response from our proxy, when trying to access https:// in the browser. But: When trying that URL on a Not-at-work-and-therefore-open-internet, I also get: ERR_NAME_NOT_RESOLVED. Are we talking 443/TCP?

When trying whispersystems.org I get redirected to signal.org.

We’ll get there, it takes time.

Can you try the following in a terminal?

curl -I https://api.signal.org
curl -I https://api.directory.signal.org

If those domains work, whitelist them in the firewall.

posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked: Unfortunately, my test-possibilities are very limited, as I’m not even able to use curl. But I have an idea, what could help. I will give feedback if that works :-)
Could you try to open both links in a browser eventually?

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked: I’d try using a shadowsocks proxy if your traffic is being blocked. This should allow you to bypass any firewall rules.

posts.name: makrohard
posts.cooked:
Unfortunately, I had no luck so far.

https://api.signal.org
https://api.directory.signal.org

are not blocked (on 443 TCP), but are not reachable either (not from work, neiter from a direct intenet access PC)

any attempt to bypass the proxy/firewall is not usable in my case. It may well work technically, but it’s not allowed in our environment and using signal desktop is not worth risking my job ;-)

Without a clear list on what to whitelist, we don’t have many chances to get Signal Desktop working here. The IT did try to guess (using the methods they have) but they have given up on that task.
